caption.p: List of selected viruses naturally infecting plants of the Solanaceae family [ 81, 82, 83, 84].

tr.td: pepper, tomato, potato, petunia, eggplant, sweet pepino, tamarillo
previously considered as one species with TNV-D (Betanecrovirus), a helper virus for Tobacco albetovirus 1, -2, -3
previously considered as one species with TNV-A (Alphanecrovirus)

More than 200 species in the genus begomovirs have been reported as naturally infecting Solanaceae species, e.g., ToLCNDV (Tomato leaf curl new delhi virus), TYLCV-Is (Tomato yellow leaf curl virus—Israel), TYLCSV (Tomato yellow leaf curl sardinia virus)
petunia, tomatillo, jimson weed, pepper, black nightshade, tobacco, tomato, eggplant
frequently large host range, often associated with alphasatellites (DNA-1) and betasatellites (DNA-β), many recently described viruses
not known but other closteroviruses are transmitted by aphids
only one report, true natural host range on Solanaceae is yet to be discovered
tobacco, pepper, tomato, potato, jimson weed, ground cherry, cape gooseberry, tomatillo, eggplant, African eggplant
moderate host range, relatively long latent period in infected host plants
extremely broad host range, infecting plants in 85 families and more than 1000 species experimentally
Solanaceous hosts mentions in VIDE database
large host range, now known as two separate species BBWV-1 and BBWV-2
potato, tobacco, tomato, jimson weed, petunia, ground cherry
leafhoppers O. orientalis and O. albicinctus
contrary to the majority of masterviruses, CpCDV can infect Solanaceae hosts
leafhoppers Orosius argentatus, O. orientalis,, Anzygina zealandica
nematode vectors, Xiphinema diversicaudatum, X. coxi
tomato, petunia, potato, black nightshade, tamarillo, cape gooseberry
nematodes X. coxi, X. diversicaudatum, X. vuittenezi
Solanaceous hosts mentions in VIDE database
nematodes Longidorus elongatus and L. attenuatus
nematodes Xiphinema americanum, X. bricolensis, X. californicum, X. rivesi
tobacco, tomato, petunia, eggplant, pepper, tamarillo
nematodes Xiphinema americanum, Longidorus or Paralongidorus spp.

TSWV (Tomato spotted wilt orthotospovirus), IYSV (Iris yellow spot orthotospovirus), CaCV (Capsicum chlorosis orthotospovirus), GBNV (Groundnut bud necrosis orthotospovirus), GRSV (Groundnut ringspot orthotospovirus), TCSV (Tomato chlorotic spot orthotospovirus), WBNV (Watermelon bud necrosis orthotospovirus), INSV (Impatiens necrotic spot orthotospovirus) and tentative members PNSV (Pepper necrotic spot virus), TZSV (Tomato zonate spot virus), TNRV (Tomato necrotic ringspot virus), TYRV (Tomato yellow ring virus)
Orthotospoviruses are transmitted by at least 13 thrip species
type species TSWV alone can naturally infect eggplant, potato, tobacco, peper, tomato, black nightshade, petunia, cape gooseberry, tomatillo, Brugmansia, bittersweet, tamarillo, jimson weed …

type species TSWV are widespread and has a very wide host range, other orthotospoviruses infect less plant species, but seem able to naturally infect Solanaceae: tomato & pepper (11 viruses), potato (7 viruses)
recognized as 6 species PeVYV-1 to -6; recently described viruses
potato, tomato, jimson weed, black nightshade, tamarillo
the virus can help the vector transmission of TMoV and TBTV (umbraviruses)

PSTVd (Potato spindle tuber viroid), TASVd (Tomato apical stunt viroid), CEVd (Citrus exocortis viroid), CSVd (Chrysanthemum stunt viroid), TPMVd (Tomato planta macho viroid), TCDVd (Tomato chlorotic dwarf viroid), PCFVd (Pepper chat fruit viroid), CLVd (Columnea latent viroid)
PSTVd alone can spread mechanically, by pollen, seed, aphids, grasshoppers, flea beetles and true bugs
PSTVd alone naturally infects ground cherry, petunia, black nightshade, potato, tomato, pepper, cape gooseberry, jimson weed and brugmansia. Most pospviroids naturally infect Solanaceous plants
requiring a helper virus for vector transmission, such as PVY or PVA
eggplant, tobacco, tomato, black nightshade, sweet pepino, potato
known for its role in mixed infections with other potato viruses
jimson weed, petunia, cape gooseberry, sweet pepino, Brugmansia
tobacco, pepper, tomato, jimson weed, African eggplant
cape gooseberry, tomato, black nightshade, tamarillo
tomato, tobacco, eggplant, black nightshade, jimson weed, ground cherry
petunia, cape gooseberry, eggplant, jimson weed, black nightshade, tobacco, potato, tomato, pepper, tamarillo
wide host range, pepper, tomato, jimson weed, physalis, tobacco, petunia
pepper, tobacco, jimson weed, petunia, physalis
petunia, cape gooseberry, eggplant, black nightshade, tobacco, tomato, potato, pepper
helper virus for satellite tobacco mosaic virus (STNV)
petunia, eggplant, potato, pepper, tomato, tamarillo
whiteflies Trialeurodes abutilonea, T. vaporariorum, and Bemisia tabaci
transmissible by aphids only in presence of TVDV
transmissible by aphids only in presence of TVDV
